newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's AAPT launches suit vs Telstra.
newsitem.headline: Australia's AAPT launches suit vs Telstra.

text.p: AAP Telecommunications Pty Ltd (AAPT), Australia's third largest telecoms carrier, said on Wednesday it had begun Federal Court proceedings restraining largest carrier, Telstra Corp, from making "misleading and deceptive statements about AAPT to AAPT customers and others".
AAPT said it was also seeking unspecified damages against the state-owned carrier for loss of reputations and business.
Local media reports put the damages claim at A$300 million.
It said such statements were in breach of the Trade Practices Act and had been in talks seeking an undertaking from Telstra to stop the behaviour.

AAPT legal director Brian Perkins said Telstra had been making "patently untrue and inaccurate statements about AAPT's financial solvency, performance and the current dispute over billing claims, which is before the New South Wales Supreme Court".
"This is yet another example of Telstra trying to abuse its significant market power which we will not tolerate.
"We have been forced to take this action to preserve AAPT's reputation and the good faith we have built with our customers," Perkins said.
A directions hearing will be held on Friday, June 20.
AAPT said it also intended to file its statement of defence and cross claims against Telstra in a separate action in the Supreme Court of New South Wales on Friday, June 13.

AAPT is 51 percent owned by Australia's domestic newsagency AAP Information Services Pty Ltd (owned 43.4 percent each by News Corp Ltd and John Fairfax Holdings Ltd ) and 24.5 percent each by Singapore Telecommunications Ltd and private New Zealand company Todd Corp.
